stem: You receive an SMS message claiming to be Uber requesting you to re-link your credit card. The link opens a web page asking for full card number and the SMS code, yet the normal payment screen in the app itself still shows your card as active.

choices.A: Open pop-up and re-link at once
choices.B: Close pop-up and check your card only through the app’s regular settings
choices.C: Send the SMS code but not the card number
choices.D: Ignore until your next ride and hope it clears

stem: An email from a crowdfunding site warns that a project will cancel your pledge unless you confirm card ownership now. The link goes to “.support-pay.com” and demands card data plus your password within the hour, though the campaign page still shows everything as normal.

choices.B: Click and enter details to keep pledge
choices.A: Log in through your usual bookmarked address and review the project there
choices.C: Reply to the email asking them for more proof to make sure they're legit.
choices.D: Delete the pledge to avoid problems

stem: A text reads: “Bank Rewards: you earned a $50 bonus. To release funds send a $2 verification deposit to wallet 9XZQ within 15 minutes.”

choices.D: Ignore and check any rewards only inside your banking app
choices.C: Call the mobile number for proof
choices.B: Forward the message to friends so they can earn too

stem: A brand-new investment app offers double interest if you finish sign-up fast. It demands a selfie with a photo of both sides of your national ID card for verification.

choices.A: Upload everything to gain the rate
choices.D: Search reviews and, if you join, register through the official app store
choices.C: Send the selfie but without the card
choices.B: Ask friends who joined to share their photos in chat

stem: Your music-streaming service emails: “Switch from card to direct debit today and save 30 % for life.” The email link asks for bank account and routing numbers.

choices.A: Enter bank details to grab discount
choices.B: Log into the service directly to verify any offer
choices.C: Reply to the email asking if it’s real
choices.D: Wait until next billing cycle before acting

stem: An online seller of rare sneakers insists you pay using the friends and family option to avoid fees, saying buyer protection slows everything. They promise a tracking number within an hour.

choices.A: Pay that way to secure the deal
choices.C: Insist on the standard goods/services payment despite higher fee
choices.D: Split payment half friends/family, half goods/services

stem: A coworker with a maxed-out personal card asks to borrow the company credit card you manage to book a flight, promising to return the cash.

choices.B: Give the card details for teamwork
choices.A: Refuse and direct them to finance for proper approval
choices.C: Book the flight yourself and hide the receipt

stem: Someone claiming to be from the revenue agency says you’re owed a refund. They ask you to install a screen-sharing app and log in to your online banking so they can issue the credit.

choices.B: End the call and verify any refund only through the official agency portal
choices.C: Ask them to mail a check instead
choices.D: Keep them talking while you record for police

stem: At a hotel, a pop-up claims your free Wi-Fi session expired and demands your card number and CVV to continue.

choices.D: Disconnect and ask the front desk before entering anything
choices.C: Use someone else’s card just in case
choices.B: Switch to cellular data but leave page open

stem: An email carrying your payment gateway’s logo warns your account will be suspended unless you run the attached “SecureUpdate.exe.” The mail greets you by username.

choices.A: Run the attachment to avoid a freeze
choices.C: Log in through the gateway’s known website and check any alerts there
choices.B: Reply asking if the patch is genuine
choices.D: Forward the mail to staff so they update too

stem: A private Telegram group promises to double any cryptocurrency you send within 24 hours, showing screenshots of big payouts. Members urge you to transfer at least 0.05 BTC immediately before the countdown ends.

choices.B: Send the minimum as a test
choices.A: Research the group independently and send nothing
choices.C: Ask admin for a smaller test amount first
choices.D: Share the link so friends can join too

stem: You spot a loose plastic cover and extra wiring on a convenience-store ATM card slot. The previous user’s card worked normally.

choices.A: Insert your card anyway—the machine works
choices.C: Use the machine but shield the keypad carefully
choices.D: Ask the store clerk to inspect the machine first

stem: Your boss emails, asking you to buy three $100 gift cards and send the codes to them. Briefly describe how you would confirm the request and handle company funds.

rubric.point: Verify the request through a direct call or internal chat
Follow the company’s normal purchasing and approval process
Recognize gift-card scam risks and suggest a safer payment method
